questions.text: A 5-year-old child develops a fever with a rash. The rash is polymorphous, itchy, starts on the trunk, does not involve the palms and soles, and disappears after a few days. The child's general condition remains good. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These features are classic for Chickenpox (Varicella infection).

  • Rash characteristics:
    • Starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities (centripetal distribution)
    • Polymorphous - lesions in different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, crusts all at the same time)
    • Intensely itchy (pruritic)
    • Spares palms and soles
  • General condition: The child usually appears well despite the rash (unless there are complications).

Explanation of other options:

Measles (Option A): Rash is non-itchy, maculopapular, begins on the face and behind the ears, spreads downward to the trunk and limbs (centrifugal spread). Associated with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots.

Fifth disease (Parvovirus B19) (Option B): Slapped cheek appearance (bright red cheeks) followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs. Usually mild and not polymorphous.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Option D): Rash begins on wrists and ankles, including palms and soles, then spreads centrally. Non-itchy and associated with toxicity, high fever, and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A child with fever presents with the following appearance, as shown. What complication can happen if this child also has an underlying chronic hematological disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of fever along with bilateral erythematous flushing or papules on the cheek, producing slapped cheek appearance, suggests the likely diagnosis of Erythema Infectiosum, also known as Fifth Disease, caused by Parvovirus B19.

  • The infection is usually mild and self-limiting in healthy children.
  • However, in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis, thalassemia), Parvovirus B19 infection can cause:
  • Transient aplastic crisis / Pure Red Cell Aplasia (PRCA)
  • Because the virus directly infects and destroys erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to a sudden halt in red cell production.
  • Laboratory clue: Reticulocyte count becomes very low or absent during a crisis.

Other possible complications: arthropathy (especially in adults), thrombocytopenia, or aseptic meningitis, but the hallmark in chronic hemolytic states is PRCA.

Explanation of other options:

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option A): Caused by poxvirus; presents as pearly, umbilicated papules, not related to parvovirus.

Thymoma (Option C): Associated with myasthenia gravis and paraneoplastic syndromes, not with Parvovirus B19.

Lymphoma (Option D): Malignant lymphoid proliferation; no direct connection to Fifth disease.

choices.text: Petechiae at the junction of the soft and hard palate- Pertussis
Dewdrops on rose petals appearance- Varicella

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match for pediatric infection and characteristic feature on clinical examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Petechiae at the junction of the soft and hard palate are a classic finding in EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) infection / infectious mononucleosis, NOT in pertussis.
  • Pertussis (whooping cough) is characterized by paroxysms of cough, inspiratory "whoop" and post-tussive vomiting, without this oral finding.

Explanation of other options:

Nagayama Spots- Human Herpes Virus-6 (Option B): Red papules on soft palate and uvula. Seen in Roseola infantum (Exanthem subitum) caused by HHV-6.

Forchheimer Spots- German Measles (Option C): Petechial spots on the soft palate. Seen in Rubella (German measles).

Dewdrops on rose petals appearance- Varicella (Option C): Clear vesicle on an erythematous base. Seen in Varicella (Chickenpox).

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy for the past week. On exam, tonsillar inflammation, palatal petechiae, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly are identified. Which of the following describes the mode of transmission of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis: Infectious Mononucleosis (EBV)

  • Cause: Epstein-Barr virus
  • Key signs:
    • Fever, sore throat
    • Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy (more than anterior)
    • Splenomegaly
    • Tonsillar enlargement with palatal petechiae

Rash in EBV infection:

  • Occurs in 10-40% of cases if ampicillin or amoxicillin is given due to misdiagnosis as streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • Type of rash: Generalized maculopapular, sometimes urticarial or petechial.
  • The rash is not an allergic reaction but an immunologically mediated phenomenon.

Mode of transmission:

  • Via salivary secretions ("kissing disease")
    • Sharing drinks, kissing, utensils, and toothbrushes.

Explanation of other options:

Blood-borne transmission (Option A): Seen with hepatitis B/C, HIV, etc.

Droplet transmission (Option B): For pathogens like influenza, pertussis.

Fecal-oral transmission (Option C): For enteric viruses like hepatitis A, poliovirus.

choices.text: Explain that medications are not routinely used in EBV infection.
Call the pharmacy and order oral prednisone 50 mg daily for 5 days (1 mg/kg/d).
Call the pharmacy and order oral acyclovir 250 mg four times per day (20 mg/kg/d).
Call the pharmacy and order oral amoxicillin 500 mg three times per day (20-45 mg/kg/d)

questions.text: The mother of a 15-year-old adolescent girl recently diagnosed with infectious mononucleosis calls for more information. She reports that her daughter, although tired, seems comfortable and is recovering nicely. She remembers that her 20-year-old son had mononucleosis when he was 10 years old, and he received an oral medication. She requests the same medication for her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary treatment:
    • Supportive care only: rest, hydration, antipyretics, and analgesics.
    • No routine antiviral or antibiotic treatment is recommended.
  • Rationale:
    • EBV infectious mononucleosis is self-limited.
    • Antivirals and steroids do not change the course of uncomplicated disease.

Explanation of other options:

Call the pharmacy and order oral prednisone 50 mg daily for 5 days (1 mg/kg/d) (Option B): Indicated only for severe complications such as impending airway obstruction (due to tonsillar hypertrophy), severe immune-mediated complications (e.g., hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia), and CNS involvement. Routine use is not recommended because it does not shorten the illness.

Call the pharmacy and order oral acyclovir 250 mg four times per day (20 mg/kg/d) (Option C): Reduces viral shedding but does not improve symptoms or shorten recovery. Therefore, not recommended for uncomplicated EBV infection.

Call the pharmacy and order oral amoxicillin 500 mg three times per day (20-45 mg/kg/d) (Option D): Antibiotics do not treat EBV. Use of ampicillin/amoxicillin in EBV infection triggers a widespread, non-allergic maculopapular rash in 70-90% of cases. Antibiotics should be used only if a proven secondary bacterial infection exists.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor response to therapy in a patient of severe congenital CMV, who is being treated with ganciclovir?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CMV monitoring in severe congenital CMV:

  • PP65 antigenemia assay detects the CMV lower matrix protein (pp65 antigen) within polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • It is a rapid, sensitive, and semi-quantitative test and is widely used both to diagnose CMV infection and monitor response to antiviral therapy (e.g., ganciclovir, valganciclovir).
  • Falling pp65 antigen levels during therapy indicate a response.

Explanation of other options:

CSF studies (Option A): CSF analysis is not routinely used to monitor therapy; it is used to rule out CNS involvement.

PCR (Option B): PCR (quantitative CMV DNA PCR) is very sensitive and can be used, but in high sero-endemic populations, pp65 antigenemia assay is preferred due to rapid turnaround and correlation with active replication.

Serum AST levels (Option D): Liver enzymes (AST/ALT) may be elevated in congenital CMV, but are nonspecific markers and not used for monitoring antiviral response.

choices.text: The most common cause of Non-Syndromic SNHL in children
Confirmation can be done by urine culture or PCR after 4 weeks of age
In developing countries, primary maternal infection can lead to congenital CMV

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Congenital CMV Infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital CMV (cytomegalovirus) is the most common non-genetic (non-syndromic) cause of sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in children.
  • It can cause hearing loss in 60% of symptomatic infants and in 5-10% of asymptomatic infants.
  • The hearing loss can be delayed, progressive, and sometimes fluctuating.

Explanation of other options:

25-30% babies are asymptomatic (Option B): In 90% of cases, congenital CMV is asymptomatic at birth. Only about 10% are symptomatic, with signs like petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, IUGR, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis. So, 25-30% asymptomatic is an underestimate.

Confirmation can be done by urine culture or PCR after 4 weeks of age (Option C): Urine or saliva culture/PCR is valid only if done within the first 3 weeks of life. After 3 weeks, positive results may reflect postnatal acquisition, not congenital infection. Therefore, after 4 weeks, these tests cannot confirm congenital CMV.

In developing countries, primary maternal infection can lead to congenital CMV (Option D): While primary maternal infection carries the highest risk (25-30%) of transmission, in developing countries (like India), most women are already CMV-seropositive. Hence, reactivation or reinfection (not primary infection) is the usual cause of congenital CMV. In developed countries, primary maternal infection during pregnancy is more often the source.

questions.text: A premature 31-week baby weighing 1.2 kg presents at birth with hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and a rash as shown in the image. The baby fails a neonatal hearing screen. CT scan of the head shows periventricular intracranial calcifications. What is the most likely congenital infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings in the question:

  • Prematurity and low birth weight (31 weeks, 1.2 kg)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice
  • Petechial rash - "blueberry muffin rash" (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis from bone marrow suppression)
  • Failed neonatal hearing screen → Sensorineural hearing loss
  • CT scan: Periventricular intracranial calcifications

These are classic for congenital CMV infection.

Characteristic features of congenital CMV:

  • The most common congenital viral infection
  • Triad:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (the most common long-term sequela)
    • Periventricular intracranial calcifications
    • Chorioretinitis
  • Other features: hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, petechiae/blueberry muffin rash, IUGR.

Explanation of other options:

HSV (Herpes simplex virus) (Option A): Presents with vesicular skin lesions, keratoconjunctivitis, encephalitis, sepsis-like illness. Intracranial calcifications are not a typical finding.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option B): Classic triad- Diffuse (scattered) intracranial calcifications, Hydrocephalus, and Chorioretinitis. Key difference- Calcifications are diffuse, not periventricular.

Parvovirus B19 (Option C): Causes severe fetal anemia → hydrops fetalis. Does not cause intracranial calcifications, hearing loss, or blueberry muffin rash.

Oral Nevirapine + Oral Zidovudine for 12 weeks

questions.text: A baby was born to an HIV+ mother, who was not taking antiretroviral therapy. The baby was started on exclusive breastfeeds. What should be the initial prophylaxis to start in the baby according to the latest guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guidelines for HIV according to NACO 2021 & WHO Updated Guidelines

  • Any baby born to an HIV+ motheris labelled as an HIV-exposed infant, regardless of the infection status
  • All HIV-exposed infantsare preferably started on exclusive breast feeds (EBF). If EBF is not possible or available, exclusive replacement feeding (ERF) can be considered, provided the family has resources and is motivated enough to continue the same.
  • All HIV-exposed infants are categorised into low-risk and high-risk as follows:
  • All HIV-exposed infants need to be started on Anti-Retroviral (ARV) Prophylaxis
  • In low-risk infants, we start oral nevirapine daily for 6 weeks
  • In high-risk infants, we start combination therapy using oral nevirapine + oral zidovudine.
  • While using combination therapy, the duration of ARV Prophylaxis depends on the mode of feeding. For EBF, it is 12 weeks,while for ERF, it is 6 weeks.

choices.text: Stop breastfeeding and start HAART in the baby
Fresh stool sample examination for Giardia
Do HIV antibody testing by ELISA
Dried blood spot for HIV, Total nucleic acid PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV+ mother develops recurrent diarrhea. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rationale:

  • In HIV-exposed infants, diagnosis cannot be made using antibody tests (e.g., ELISA) before 18 months of age because maternal IgG antibodies cross the placenta and can persist up to 18 months, leading to false positives.
  • NACO EID (Early Infant Diagnosis) protocol:
    1. At 6 weeks of age:
      • Perform HIV-1 Total Nucleic Acid (TNA) PCR using a dried blood spot (DBS).
      • If the infant develops symptoms suggestive of HIV at any age before that (e.g., recurrent diarrhea, failure to thrive, severe infections), testing must be done immediately, without waiting for 6 weeks.
    2. If the test is positive:
      • Confirm with a second DBS TNA PCR from a fresh sample.
    3. If both are positive:
      • Start ART immediately.
    4. If the second test is negative:
      • Treat as not confirmed and follow up with repeat testing.

Key Update (NACO 2020):

  • Total Nucleic Acid PCR (TNA PCR) has replaced HIV DNA PCR for early diagnosis in infants.
  • Testing is recommended at 6 weeks of age OR earlier if the infant becomes symptomatic.

Explanation of other options:

Stop breastfeeding and start HAART (Option A): Breastfeeding is not stopped solely on the basis of symptoms. ART is started only after a confirmed diagnosis.

Fresh stool examination for Giardia (Option B): Recurrent diarrhea in an HIV-exposed infant must first raise the suspicion of HIV infection itself; opportunistic infections become relevant after confirmation of HIV.

HIV Antibody testing (ELISA) (Option C): Not recommended before 18 months of age because maternal antibodies cause false positives.

questions.text: A child develops a fever with a rash. The pediatrician noticed the lesion shown below in the mouth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:


  • Key clue: Koplik spots - small bluish-white spots with a red base, seen on the buccal mucosa, opposite the lower 2nd molars.
    • Measles (Rubeola) classic triad:
    • Fever
    • 3 C's - Cough, Coryza, Conjunctivitis
  • Followed by maculopapular rash that starts behind the ears and spreads downwards.
  • Rash: Erythematous, non-itchy, appears 2-3 days after prodromal symptoms. Fades in the same order and leaves a brownish discoloration.

Explanation of other options:

Mumps (Option B): Characteristic feature: Painful parotid swelling (parotitis). No Koplik spots or generalized rash in the typical presentation.

Rubella (German Measles) (Option C): Rash is similar to measles but milder, starts on face and spreads rapidly. No Koplik spots; instead, Forchheimer spots (petechiae on soft palate) may be seen. Associated with postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy.

Chicken Pox (Varicella) (Option B): Rash- Vesicular (dew-drop on rose petal), itchy, appears in crops and at different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, crusts). No Koplik spots.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A child at birth has sensorineural hearing loss and a heart defect (PDA). Examination of the eyes revealed the following findings. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS):

  1. Sensorineural hearing loss - most common finding
  2. Ocular findings -
  • Congenital cataract
  • Salt-and-pepper retinopathy (fundus shows mottled pigmentation)
  1. Cardiac defect - classically Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), sometimes peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis

Infection occurs when the mother acquires Rubella infection during early pregnancy (especially the first trimester).

Explanation of other options:

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) (Option A):

  • Key congenital findings:
    • Periventricular intracranial calcifications
    • Microcephaly
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • SNHL
  • Does not classically cause PDA or congenital cataract.
  • Fundus finding: Chorioretinitis, not salt-and-pepper retinopathy.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option B):

  • Classic triad:
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications
  • No PDA or congenital cataract.
  • Fundus: Focal necrotizing chorioretinitis, not salt-and-pepper.

Chicken Pox (Congenital Varicella Syndrome) (Option D):

  • Key features:
    • Limb hypoplasia
    • Cicatricial (scarred) skin lesions
    • Neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy)
    • Eye defects (microphthalmia, chorioretinitis)
  • Not associated with PDA or the Rubella triad.

questions.text: An infant has paroxysms of nocturnal cough with fever. The child also has chest retractions, gasping, and cyanosis. TLC is 50000 with lymphocytosis. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis: Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

  • Key findings:
    • Paroxysmal cough (especially nocturnal)
    • Cyanosis/apnea instead of a classic "whoop" (common in infants)
    • Extreme lymphocytic leukocytosis (>50,000/mm³)
    • Bordetella pertussis infection

Treatment

  • Macrolides (Azithromycin or Erythromycin) are the drugs of choice
    • They eradicate B. pertussis from the respiratory tract and reduce communicability, but do not shorten the duration of symptoms (which are toxin-mediated).
  • Erythromycin is also given as chemoprophylaxis to close contacts, especially for infants.

Explanation of other options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): Alternative only when macrolides are contraindicated. Not first-line.

Amoxicillin (Option B): Used for common bacterial respiratory infections. Ineffective against B. pertussis.

Clindamycin (Option D): No role in pertussis. Active against anaerobes and Gram-positive cocci.

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for Whooping cough?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gold standard test:
    • Culture of Bordetella pertussis from a deep nasopharyngeal swab or aspirate.
  • Why a nasopharyngeal swab?
    • pertussis attaches to ciliated epithelial cells of the nasopharynx.
    • It is rarely found in sputum or tracheal aspirates, especially early in illness.
  • Procedure:
    • Use Dacron or calcium alginate swabs (not cotton).
    • Keep in place 15-30 seconds or until the child coughs.
  • Media:
    • Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with horse blood and cephalexin
    • Stainer-Scholte medium
  • Appearance: Colonies appear in 5-7 days as small, glistening ("mercury drop") colonies.
  • Note:
    • PCR is faster and widely used, but culture remains the gold standard because of its specificity.

Explanation of other options:

Tracheal aspirate culture (Option A): Invasive and not routinely needed. Pertussis organisms are better recovered from the nasopharynx.

Cough plate culture (Option B): Old method- holding a plate in front of the patient's mouth while coughing. Obsolete because it is less sensitive and prone to contamination.

Sputum culture (Option D): Ineffective- Bordetella pertussis is localized in the upper airway (nasopharynx). Rarely present in sputum, especially in the early catarrhal stage.

questions.text: Not a feature of early congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clutton's joints refer to bilateral knee swelling or effusion, seen in late congenital syphilis, appearing beyond 2 years of age. This is not a feature of early congenital syphilis. All others are features of early congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presented with high grade fever for 3 days, followed by the onset of non-pruritic, maculopapular rash. The rash first appeared on the trunk and spread to the face but spared the palms and soles. On examination, there was no lymphadenopathy but aphthous ulcer-like lesions were found on the uvula and the uvulo-palatoglossal junction, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key diagnostic clues:

  1. Fever followed by rash:
    • Roseola infantum (Exanthem subitum, Sixth disease) has a high fever for 3-5 days, after which fever subsides and a maculopapular rash appears.
  2. Rash distribution:
    • Starts on the trunk → spreads to neck and face, sparing palms and soles.
  3. Enanthem:
    • Nagayama spots: Erythematous papules/ulcers on the uvula and soft palate.
  4. Age:
    • Typically affects infants and toddlers (6 months - 3 years).
  5. Causative agent:
    • Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6) (most common) or HHV-7.

Explanation of other options:

Coxsackievirus A16 (Option A): Causes Hand-Foot-and-Mouth Disease with vesicular lesions on hands, feet, and oral mucosa (not Nagayama spots) and a rash involves palms and soles.

Human Parvovirus B19 (Option B): Causes Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease). "Slapped cheek" facial rash followed by lacy, reticular rash on the trunk. Does not present with Nagayama spots.

Rubella virus (Option D): Rash begins on the face and spreads downward. Postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy is characteristic. No Nagayama spots.

questions.text: A 38-week gestation male infant was precipitously delivered vaginally in the emergency department. Weight and head circumference are less than 5th percentile, and length at 10th percentile. He has hepatosplenomegaly and a petechial rash. Notable laboratory results include platelets of 22,000/mm3 and elevated total and direct bilirubin levels. CT of the head shows bilateral intracranial calcifications with several around the basal ganglia and obstructive hydrocephalus. Ophthalmologic examination reveals chorioretinitis. What is the most likely cause of the patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key features in this case:

  1. Neuroimaging:
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications including basal ganglia
    • Obstructive hydrocephalus
  2. Ophthalmology:
    • Chorioretinitis
  3. Other findings:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, thrombocytopenia, growth restriction.

These features correspond to the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis:

Hydrocephalus + Diffuse intracranial calcifications + Chorioretinitis

This triad is very specific for Toxoplasma gondii infection acquired in utero.

Explanation of other options:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option A):

  • Key pattern:
    • Periventricular intracranial calcifications (clustered around ventricles)
    • Microcephaly (not hydrocephalus)
  • Can also cause chorioretinitis and SNHL, but:
    • Hydrocephalus is uncommon
    • Calcifications are not diffuse

Rubella virus (Option B):

  • Classic triad of congenital rubella:
    1. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) / congenital heart disease
    2. Cataracts or "salt and pepper" retinopathy
    3. Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis are NOT features of rubella.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) (Option D):

  • Findings:
    • Vesicular skin lesions, scarring
    • Encephalitis (temporal lobe predilection)
    • Hepatomegaly, seizures
  • Does not cause intracranial calcifications and rarely causes hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male with sickle cell disease presents with fever for 2 days and vague complaints of arthralgias. He has a history of multiple sickle cell crises and subsequent admissions. For which of the following infections is this patient at higher risk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Splenic dysfunction in sickle cell disease

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Repeated vaso-occlusion in sickle cell disease causes splenic infarctions → progressive autosplenectomy(functional asplenia by ~5 years of age).
    • Loss of splenic function impairs the clearance of encapsulated organisms.
  • High-risk encapsulated organisms:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Haemophilus influenzae type b
    • Neisseria meningitidis
    • Salmonella spp. (especially for osteomyelitis)

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most important:

  • The most common causes of sepsis, meningitis, and overwhelming infections in asplenic children.
  • Mortality is high if not treated early.

Explanation of other options:

Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option A): Gram-negative bacillus, but not a classic encapsulated pathogen of concern in asplenia.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Can cause infections, but splenic dysfunction does not increase risk beyond normal.

Enterococcus (Option D): Not encapsulated, and risk is not increased due to splenic dysfunction.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with high chills with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and a lesion as shown in the picture. Peripheral blood showed thrombocytopenia and transaminitis. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture (high fever with chills, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, transaminitis) along with a single, black, painless eschar (necrotic scab) is highly suggestive of Scrub Typhus, a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.
  • Drug of Choice: Doxycycline
    • Even in children below 8 years, doxycycline is the first-line treatment because of its life-saving effect in rickettsial diseases.
    • Dose: 2.2 mg/kg/dose twice daily for 5-7 days.

Key Features of Scrub Typhus:

  • Incubation period: 10-12 days
  • Clinical features:
    • Sudden high fever with chills, headache, and myalgia.
    • Rash (maculopapular) on day 4-5, occurs in <50%.
    • Hepatomegaly (2/3), splenomegaly (1/3), generalized lymphadenopathy.
    • GIT symptoms in ~40%.
    • Hallmark: Single painless eschar with black crust at the site of the chigger bite.
    • Untreated cases: fever persists into the 3rd week.
    • Complications: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), ARDS, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis.
  • Investigations:
    • Thrombocytopenia and transaminitis are common.
    • Weil-Felix test may be positive, but it is insensitive.
    • IgM ELISA is more specific.

Explanation of other options:

Azithromycin (Option A): Second-line drug; reserved for pregnant patients or doxycycline-resistant cases.

Penicillin G (Option C): Ineffective against rickettsial diseases.

Levofloxacin (Option D): Fluoroquinolones have limited or no efficacy for scrub typhus.
